summary.seg: A fragment of a calendar or world-chronicle, probably English and made c. 1300. A single leaf of parchment, stiff due to the thickness of the membrane and a layer of adhesive on the verso. The leaf has been trimmed significantly and evidence of the loss of text and decoration is visible around the entire perimeter. The fragment was once part of the former binding of Cambridge, Gonville and Caius MS 345/620 , where it was probably used as the left pastedown; MS 345/620 was rebound in 1913, and this fragment was extracted from the former binding and retained in a separate enclosure.

The leaf contains part of a calendar, and due to the thickness of the membrane and the selection of events recorded, M. R. James, who examined the fragment during the preparation of his Catalogue of the Gonville and Caius College manuscripts suggested that the leaf may have once been part of a 'placard', and felt that it was 'evidently made to be hung up in a church or other public place'. James also suggested that due to the mention of the 'deposition of St Edward' ('Deposicionis sancti edwardi'), the placard may have once been connected with Westminster Abbey where he was buried.

The calendrical events are recorded in roughly chronological order, describing the events of the first Easter ('Termino pasche', 'Die pasche'), then the establishment of Christianity and the arrival of Christianity in England ('Anno ab aduentu prime christianitatis', 'Ab aduentu christianitatis in angliam'), the burial of Edward of the Confessor 6th Jan 1066 ('Deposicionis sancti edwardi et aduentu ...'), the martyrdom of Thomas Becket on 29 December 1170 ('A passione beati thome martyris'), the translation of his body on 7 July 1220 ('A translatione eiusdem'), and then, slightly out of sequence, a reference to the papal interdict of 23 March 1208 - 2 July 1214 ('Ab interdicto generali per angliam'). It is possible that the number of years since each event had taken place, i.e., 'X years since the death of King Edward the Confessor' were recorded on the now-missing right-hand side of the fragment, which, had it survived, would have allowed for precise dating of the leaf.

Transcription:
Claue terminorum
Termino pasche
Die pasche
Anno ab aduentu prime christianitatis
Ab aduentu christianitatis in angliam
Deposicionis sancti edwardi et aduentu
A passione beati thome martyris

extent.seg: Fragment, comprising a single leaf of thick parchment, later used as part of the binding (? a pastedown) in Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 345/620.

supportDesc.condition: Stiff parchment due to the thickness of the membrane and an adhesive residue on the verso. Slightly wormed, but generally in good condition, text legible. Trimmed from its original size with losses to text and decoration along all four edges of the fragment. Minor losses to text and decoration due to abrasions.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. 7 full lines and 2 partial lines visible.

decoNote.p: Red 'lombardic' capitals with blue flourishing (and the reverse) at the start of each line of text.

note.p: The shelfmark of the volume from which the fragment was extracted present in pencil on f. 1v, '345/620'.
The name 'Thomas' in ink on f. 1r in a ?16th century hand.
Traces of a note in ink on f. 1v, now illegible.

origin.origDate: Probably made in the late 13th century or the early 14th century.
origin.note: M. R. James suggested that the 'reference to the deposition of St Edward may point to Westminster'.

provenance.p: Removed from the binding of Cambridge, Gonville and Caius, MS 345/620 .

acquisition.p: Bound separately as Cambridge, Gonville and Caius, 803/807, no. 57 after the rebinding of Cambridge, Gonville and Caius MS 345/620 in 1913.

recordHist.source: This catalogue description draws on M. R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, Vol. 1 (Cambridge, 1907), MS 345/620.
